bug.short_desc: JVMTI profiler. Redundant spaces are added to the trace output by CG profiler

long_desc.thetext:
Call graph profiler puts extra spaces in the parameters of method entry and exit in the trace output.
Example: ... <methodEntry threadIdRef="1" time="1159951851.299685478" methodIdRef=" 69905" classIdRef=" 422" ticket="1" stackDepth="2"/> <methodExit threadIdRef="1" methodIdRef=" 69905" classIdRef=" 422" ticket="1" time="1159951851.317874193"/> <methodExit threadIdRef="1" methodIdRef=" 69903" classIdRef=" 421" ticket="0" time="1159951851.317972183"/> ...
Following error can be thrown if the argumet is not trimmed: java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: " 421"
Also these spaces increase size of the trace output up to 50%.
build: TPTP-4.3.0-200610010100 different linux configuration (ia32, IPF) different JVMs (SUN, JRockit) profiling with and without filters
The C function sprintf() does not work as expected.

Slava - I am not seeing any behavior issues on the client side with the spaces in the XML. Its on the standalone mode where this is substantially increasing the size of the file. Given our new path - identify why sprintf is causing this and leave it at that. We will need the time for other planned activities.
The bug fixed
verified using build TPTP-4.3.0-200610190100

bug.short_desc: Support group/other file rights

long_desc.thetext: Currently the embedded CVS client fails to receive file rights correctly from the CVS server, it handles only user rights.
We would require API from Resources in order to make this work.
Can I do anything about it that would help the cause?

bug.short_desc: [hotbug][web services] webservice.NewProjectListener initialization takes 35% cpu time of CommonNavigator.createPartControl()

long_desc.thetext: For our test case (statup workbench), Navigator.createPartControl() takes only 561 msec in previours version. But now, CommonNavigator.createPartControl() takes 3,016 msec. 1,059 msec (35%) is comsumed in webservice.NewProjectListener initialization.
Could you provide more details of your analysis? How many projects do you have in the workspace? Do you have any web services at all?

Created an attachment (id=51453) cpu sampling
There are 2 projects. (One is the EAR project for the other.) One project has web service. But I do not think it depends on the project in a workspace. I attached a capture of YourKit cpu sampling.

Hot-bug request information
1. Affiliation: IBM 2. Release you want this bug to be fixed in: 1.5.2 3. Justify why this is a hot bug and why it needs to be fixed in that release: Performance.

Hi,
Can you try running your tests again with the jar overlay associated with https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=158339. I think it should drop the amount of time spent in the NewProjectListener class.
Also, here is why, in general, the web service content extension will be slower on startup. We used to always show the web service explorer node, even if the use did not have web services at all. So, now, we only show the web service node if it is applicable, meaning if there are any services or service refs. This usability enhancement will take a bit longer in startup, but it should not be drastic. Hopefully, this is a duplicate of the bug 158339.
Thanks.

(In reply to comment #4) > Can you try running your tests again with the jar overlay associated with > https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=158339.
I tried the patch, and found it is slower than original. [Original] WebServicesManager.addArtifactEdit() takes 788 msec. Most of time is cosumed for WSDDArtifactEdit.getWSDDArtifactEditForRead(), 787 msec. [Patch] WebServicesManager.addArtifactEdit() takes 1,547 msec. WSDDArtifactEdit.getWSDDArtifactEditForRead()takes 751 msec (almost same as original.) WSDDArtifactEdit.getWebServices() takes 640 msec. So it seems this causes regression to the original.

The patch for that defect was found to be unhelpful due to a problem with our edit model caching too aggressively.
However, I am attaching a patch here which should resolve the startup time of the navigator.
Created an attachment (id=51716) Proposed patch

Created an attachment (id=51717) Jar Overlay for org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.webservice.ui
Please try your test again with this class file overlay into your org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.webservice.ui plugin jar.

(In reply to comment #8) > Created an attachment (id=51717) [edit] > Jar Overlay for org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.webservice.ui > Please try your test again with this class file overlay into your > org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.webservice.ui plugin jar.
This patch is effective. CommonNavigator.createPartControl() now takes 2,199 msec. And total startup time is also reduced. (14.2 sec -> 12.2 sec)

The patch here is very straightforward. We had two start() methods on the WebServiceSynchronization content extension, one which invokes default, which we were calling, and one which creates a new job and runs in that job. We now call this job method because the whole point of this design was to have this running in the background and not holding up navigator or workbench start up. So, the change is to ensure the web service collection is happening in a job. The patch is attached, tested, profiled, and ready for review.
approve.
approve

+1 for WTP 1.5.2
Tiny patch resulting in big performance improvement.
This is released for the 101706 WTP 1.5.2 and 2.0 builds.
Verified 101906.

bug.short_desc: Unable to configure xlint cantFindType message on the AspectJ Compiler Preferences page

long_desc.thetext:
There is currently no option on the AspectJ Compiler Preferences page (Window > Preferences > AspectJ Compiler) to enable configuring the severity of the cantFindType xlint message. By default this message is an error.
This is also the case for the project specific page.

As a quick note, there are other xlint options which aren't exposed in the UI (see the list of xlint options mentioned in bug 151707 to compare). I believe these are
cantFindType cantFindTypeAffectingJoinPointMatch calculatingSerialVersionUID
This should go into 1.4.1
I believe "cantFindTypeAffectingJoinPointMatch" should be "cantFindTypeAffectingJPMatch", as specified in the XlintDefault.properties file, no?

Yes; the problem is that runtime assumes that the only client of this class is TextCompartmentEditPart while there is a special ITextAwareEditPart interface that captures text aspect of an edit part.

I have verified that this issue occurs in 1.0.1. We should investigate this as a regression that affects the generated code from the tooling side.

The cast was introduced as part of https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=148244 Generally, it seems to be bad idea to deliver all fixes from maintenance at once few days prior to milestone.
Created an attachment (id=51484) Patch to avoid ClassCastException

Created an attachment (id=51497) updated patch
Added a new patch. A generated GMF editor would have the same issue that bugzilla#148244 was fixing. Now instead of checking if the editpart is a TextCompartmentEditPart, the TextDirectEditManager will get the figure and check if it is an instance of WrapLabel.
Committed to R1_0_maintenance
getFont is available for any IFigure, why the patch restricts font change to WrapLabels only? At least, standard Labels seem worth being handled as well.

I agree that the TextDirectEditManager could be made more generic. However, I didn't see the point in making it more generic for 1.0.1. Are you using the TextDirectEditManager for editparts whose figure is not a WrapLabel? If you want this made more generic, why don't you create a new bugzilla for 2.0?

(In reply to comment #9) > I agree that the TextDirectEditManager could be made more generic. However, I > didn't see the point in making it more generic for 1.0.1.
Well, TextDirectEditManager *is* generic enough (e.g. #getScaledFont), it's the fix for #148244 that introduced 'not-generic' code for the problem.
> Are you using the TextDirectEditManager for editparts whose figure > is not a WrapLabel? Yes.
> If you want this made more generic, why don't you create a new bugzilla for 2.0? Given the class was 'generic' prior to the #148244, should I just reopen that request with "the patch should be revised with other usecases in mind"?

The code in the method show(Point location) added for bugzilla#148244 uses methods on WrapLabel. (These methods are also available on GEF's Label class and if WrapLabel extended GEF's Label, as it probably should, this new code would have been specific to GEF's Label class.)
Are you using this TextDirectEditManager class for editparts whose figures are GEF's Labels or other figures?
We could create a subclass of TextDirectEditManager for use with WrapLabels. Would this solve your issues?
I tested the fix for bugzilla#148244 on the generated FlowChart GMF example and it works there so that must be using WrapLabels.

With https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=135694, TextDirectEditManager should respect figures other than WrapLabel (be 'generic'). Patches applied to the class should be 'generic'. If it's possible to have some functionality both for WrapLabels and Labels (especially when it gets to functionality available from IFugure, like #getFont()), this should be handled within TextDirectEditManager.
To me, there's no sense in subclass of TextDirectEditManager dedicated to WrapLabels. Instead, functionality present in common superclass should be used (i.e. font, bounds are available from IFigure, iconBounds - from Label).
What's wrong with replacing next line in the patch WrapLabel fig = (WrapLabel) getEditPart().getFigure(); with IFigure fig = this.getEditPart().getFigure();
(and removing instanceof WrapLabel checks altogether)?

Dmitri, you are right, we can just use IFigure when the font is retrieved. However, in the method show(Point location) it uses methods only on WrapLabel and Label. I can handle both cases here too (instead of just the WrapLabel case), but the TextDirectEditManager is still going to have specific code for Label/WrapLabel. We can't get rid of the check for an instanceof WrapLabel in the method show(Point location) because WrapLabel does not subclass Label (although it probably should).
Made the show() method work with IFigure and show(Point) method work with Labels or WrapLabels to be more generic.
Great! Guess, the fix will be merged into HEAD till M2, right?

Can you add this patch please to M2 as this is a serious issue for me?
Thanks
Committed change to head as well.
*** Bug 160445 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Please let me know the exact Eclipse version that you are using. I assume that you are using the download.eclipse.org/technology/mylar/update-site/e3.2 update site. Also, please send me the full error log (<eclipse>/.metadata/.log) because this message only shows that the plug-in failed to load, but does not show why. In the meantime, some things to try: * Make sure that you're updating all of the Mylar features you have (e.g. an 0.6.2 Bugzilla Connector will fail to work with 0.7.0 causing this kind of failure). * Make sure that you use the "Search for new features.." when installing instead of "Search for updates..". The latter does not work correctly and can fail to install a dependent feature.
Let me know how it goes.

The problem is as quoted below. I just re-verified that we are correctly distributing that JAR, and that I can install into a clean 3.2 Eclipse and everything starts correctly. So we need to figure out what on your environment is causing the httpclient library to fail to load. It's most likely another plug-in, or an old Mylar plug-in that's loading bug shouldn't. Please verify that you can install Mylar 0.7.0 into a freshly-downloaded Eclipse. Assuming that works, go into your plugins/ and features/ directories and delete all old Mylar versions (pre 0.7.0). Let me know if that resolves the problem. Fyi nothing has changed in how we distribute httpclient between 0.6.2 and 0.7.0, so this is likely the problem, or another plug-in that's redistributing that library is causing it. Let me know how it goes.
> Root exception: > java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: > org/apache/commons/httpclient/protocol/ProtocolSocketFactory > at > org.eclipse.mylar.tasks.ui.TasksUiPlugin.start(TasksUiPlugin.java:391) > > For some reason that apache library is not loading. I'm trying to > reproduce now with a clean Eclipse 3.2.1. In the meantime, are you using > a clean Eclipse 3.2 (i.e. freshly downloaded), or one with other stuff > installed? If it's the latter, you could try going into your plugins/ and > features/ directories and removing all the org.eclipse.mylar.. plug-ins, > then restarting, then re-installing.
Any luck Martin?

Could this be hardware/threading related? The machines that are being installed on and are having problems are all 2 CPU 3.2 GHx Xeons.

These stack traces do not have the NoClassDefFoundError mentioned comment#2, so I think we need to figure out if this is a race condition, or perhaps some kind of problem with the BEA VM. Fyi, I run on a 2GHz Core Duo which Windows thinks has 2 CPUs, but it's possible that multicores do threading differently.
Martin: I would really like to get to the bottom of this. I will try to find a dual Xeon to test on, but that may take a few days. In the meantime, could you please try to copy over this Eclipse to a single core machine and see if the error still happens?

Ugh. Well, at least we have diagnosed the problem, good work all!
We did not make any substantial change in the startup code between 0.6.2 and 0.7.0, so it will take some work to figure out how we are triggering this behavior, which is likely a bug in the BEA VM. I assume that you guys were using the latest JRockit 5.0 R26 VM? http://commerce.bea.com/products/weblogicjrockit/5.0/jr_50.jsp?
Rob: please update the FAQ indicating this limitation and pointing to this bug, and suggesting using the Sun VM or 0.6.2 as a work-around. I can't investigate work-around until Monday, so I'll probably post a message to the list.
Martin: since this is blocking you and potentially others from updating I'm hoping that we can release an new build that works around this next week.
Yes, my tests were done using jrockit-R26.4.0-jdk1.5.0_06-win-ia32.

Yes, my tests were done using jrockit-R26.4.0-jdk1.5.0_06-win-ia32.
Your comment was:
Yes I was using the lastest Jrockit VM.
As regards a fix I have a work around for our installations at this point. I created a zip file of 0.6.2 and am having people set up using this ( my doc mentions it is a temporary hack :) )

Fixed by making our extension point loading policy lazier. Rob: fyi I had to remove the migration code from the constructor of WorkspaceAwareContextStore and put it into TasksUiPlugin.start(). From now on we will need to think twice before doing anything fancy of that sort in the constructor of an extension point, because it looks like that can trigger class loading bugs in the jrockit.
Martin: a dev build will be available for you to test this with in about 15 minutes. Please use the following update site: download.eclipse.org/technology/mylar/update-site/dev and verify that that it solves the problem for you. Then we will likely cut a 0.7.0.1 build to make this fix generally available.
Looks great using the dev update site. Thanks for the quick turnaround.

Great, thanks for verifying. We haven't had to do a service build for about a year, but since this could hit other BEA JRockit users this warrants it and 0.7.0.1 will be available for download and announced on the newsgroup within a few hours.
The changes in comment#18 should makes us more robust to similar VM bugs or timeouts, since they delay extension point initialization until after plug-in startup.

bug.short_desc: DanglingHREFException in case of creation and deletion of sub-sub elements

long_desc.thetext:
We're creating an object model using the generic API of the EDataObjects, EClasses etc. In this case we have hierarchies up to three levels. Root --> SubLevel --> SubSubLevel.
We're trying to create the complete hierarchy in one "business logic" step, EDataObject root = OurFactory.getRoot(); root.createDataObject("subLevel"); subLevel.createDataObject("subSubLevel");
During the business logic the subLevel we just created must be removed again. (It's a CSV-File where the next line leads to the deletion of the "just created" record)
We're using the EMF Remove command to remove the subLevel, expecting that also the subSub Objects will be removed.
After this the EDataGraph (were the root is held) has a dangling references of the SubSub object.
Change summary looks something like this: <objectChanges> <value xsi:type="sdo_1:EChangeSummarySetting" featureName="factor" set="false"/> <value xsi:type="sdo_1:EChangeSummarySetting" featureName="lowerBound" set="false"/> <value xsi:type="sdo_1:EChangeSummarySetting" featureName="amount" set="false"/> </objectChanges>
Please note that the key attribute is missing for this.
As i mentioned, the expected behaviour would be that the subSub object will be removed too.

Andreas,
A remove command won't remove all references to an object. A delete command would do that. In terms of the change description, when a node is removed, all the children of that node become detached from the graph as well, but there won't be change description entries for such children because the children are still attached to their parent even if the parent is no longer attached to the graph.

bug.short_desc: [FastViews] RCP: possibility to customize fast view

long_desc.thetext: please add a posibility to use the fast view toolbar/control in a application which overrides createWindowContents in WorkbenchWindowAdvisor!!!

We're deprecating the FVB so no work is anticipated here...
BTW, we're already looking at a better way to allow RCP clients to access our 'internal' layout code...
so is there a bug open for "better way to allow RCP clients to access our 'internal' layout code..."? can you post the bug #

No bug # per se. We're in design discussions around the current presentation code in general and being better at this is one of the design requriements...
We're aiming at a more Model/View approach that would allow us to much more amenable to replacement of discreet components. The 'model' would support some defined structure which would be 'rendered' by some WBW implementation. This would entail us opening up our various 'renders' (of which the TrimLayout would be one) so that RCP clients could choose between our default renderer for a particular model or they could replace the renderer at any level (i.e. you could leave the 'shell' renderer in place (controlling the 'trim' and the 'center') while replacing the renderer for the "TabStack'.
No guarantees here (we're still in the blue-sky brainstorming) but we understand that making this separation possible is -required- for any reasonable replacement for our current presentation story.

bug.short_desc: [compiler] missing warnings for deprecated member types

long_desc.thetext: Reproduced. Added DeprecatedTest#test015 to 018, Deprecated15Tests#test002 and DependencyTests#test0100, of which all but two are inactive.

The issue came from the fact that, in case of a forward reference to a member type, the deprecation detection started with the said member type and omitted to climb up the enclosing types chain to detect potential implicit deprecation.
Created an attachment (id=51832) Fix + test cases tuning
Released for 3.3 M3.
What about local types ?
Opened bug 161214 for fup items.
Verified for 3.3 M3 using warm-up build I20061030-0800

From the CVSUI end, it looks like we're doing something in the UI thread on initialization but nothing immediatley popped out on inspection.
It looks like Mylar is trying to get at the ActiveChangeSetManager on startup by using the UI thread. This should be moved off to a background thread to prevent this scenario from occurring. Moving over to Mylar.

Andreas: what version of Mylar are you using?
Bogdan: in recent versions we have been accessing the ActiveChangeSetManager not directly within the start() method of the plug-in but within a getDisplay().asyncExec(..) call within the startup. Do you foresee this causing a problem? I guess we could start it as a separate Job, but with the async in place I have never seen this error.

I believe the original version I recorded this against was 0.2 as this bug shows. I've now retested (currently running 0.7.0.1) and cannot see the exception generated. I suggest closing the bug a WFM or Invalid?
Thanks for the info Andreas. This should no longer be possible, but please reopen if you see anything similar.

bug.short_desc: [1.5][compiler] wrongly reports ambiguous method error

long_desc.thetext: I verified that using JDK 1.5.0_08, javac does not complain on this code...

Reproduced with HEAD. According to JLS 15.12.2, the second method is strictly more specific than the first one, hence maximally specific, and being the sole method to be maximally specific, it is the most specific method, and the call is not ambiguous. Added (inactive) test cases #23 and 24 to AmbiguousMethodTest.

We rawify a bit too aggressively the parameters in ParametrizedGenericMethodBinding#tiebreakMethod in the case of a static method. A first attempt to fix that failed in the cases where the caller was already rawified. Currently testing less an agressive approach (using the upper bounds to build a parametrized generic method to use as the tiebreak).

Created an attachment (id=52197) Fix + test case
In case the considered method is static, we build a tiebreak method that does not rawify its arguments types.
Released for 3.3 M3.
Verified for 3.3 M3 using warm-up build I20061030-0800

bug.short_desc: Feature installation not possible on low disk space

long_desc.thetext:
In bug 154331 a problem was experienced where feature installation failed due to low disc space. In this case the feature size was erroneously reported to be 12GB. The problems with the update manager behaviour are:
- no indication of feature size is given (spotting the 12GB would have been a good information) - no error message is given on low disc space- only the "Finish" button becomes disabled
Any thoughts on this? Otherwise lets close as wontfix?

One of the last pages of the install wizards lists required and available space at the bottom of the page. The problem in bug 154331 was that the size reported by the feature was 1000 times greater than needed.
You are right that we can draw attention to insufficient space more.
I will convert this into an enhancement request and leave it active.
Any chance looking into this for 3.4?
No work will be done in Platform/Update in 3.4 unless it is a critical fix and a patch is contributed. Most of our focus is on the new provisioning mechanism (P2).

- what is short cut do you use to invoke code assist? - what short cut is shown for 'Default' in the menu Edit > Content Assist? - please attach your preferences to this bug report (File > Export...)
Can you provide steps? It works for me using these steps: 1. download Eclipse SDK 3.2.1 and install into empty directory 2. start with fresh workspace 3. create Java project 'P' with class 'Foo' 4. use Ctrl+Space to invoke code assist inside the class

I see two bugs here 1) we do not handle the case where no key binding is assigned ==> this needs to be fixed for 3.2.2 2) some how the key binding got lost or cannot be found (see also bug 160045)

Created an attachment (id=51617) Fix for problem 1)
This patch fixes problem 1 but is not yet released in order to get more info, especially to see whether the tests will fail again.
Created an attachment (id=51618) Improved patch for problem 1)

bug.short_desc: 'New Example' wizard text not translated for OCL examples

long_desc.thetext: The org.eclipse.emf.ocl.examples plug-in's translation fragments do not have translations of any of the text that appears in the 'New Example' wizard, including the category name, example name, and example description.

All of the relevant text in the plugin.xml is externalized in the plugin.properties file. Whenever the Eclipse Translation Project takes over translation, then translations of these strings will become available.

long_desc.thetext:
I've tried adding an attachment twice to bug 159714 on OSX using Safari 2.0.4 (419.3). But on the third try I used Firefox 1.5.0.6 on OS X and it succeeded. Both times I received the failure I received the following...
"Internal Server Error
The server encountered an internal error or misconfiguration and was unable to complete your request.
Please contact the server administrator, webmaster@eclipse.org and inform them of the time the error occurred, and anything you might have done that may have caused the error.
More information about this error may be available in the server error log.
Additionally, a 400 Bad Request error was encountered while trying to use an ErrorDocument to handle the request."
The attachment was a patch that contains the following text...
### Eclipse Workspace Patch 1.0 #P org.eclipse.jface.databinding Index: src/org/eclipse/jface/databinding/Binding.java =================================================================== RCS file: /cvsroot/eclipse/org.eclipse.jface.databinding/src/org/eclipse/jface/databinding/Binding.java,v retrieving revision 1.2 diff -u -r1.2 Binding.java --- src/org/eclipse/jface/databinding/Binding.java 1 Sep 2006 01:35:13 -0000 1.2 +++ src/org/eclipse/jface/databinding/Binding.java 4 Oct 2006 13:01:39 -0000 @@ -20,8 +20,6 @@ /** * The interface that represents a binding between a model and a target. * - * This interface is not intended to be implemented by clients. - * * @since 1.0 */ public abstract class Binding {

Also I don't have any proof that this has anything to do with Safari. I've had issues with uploads in the past but just thought that they were a flaky connection. I've created attachments before with Safari and they've uploaded fine.
Can't seem to reproduce this...

(In reply to comment #2) > Can't seem to reproduce this... >
OK. I'll just assume for now that it's something on my side but wanted to get it documented.
Thanks. I'll close this as "worksforme". Feel free to reopen if this happens again.
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: [OutlineView] Outline View always listens and resolves elements

long_desc.thetext:
Issue 1: The Tree Outline View seems to always be listening to events even when the outline view is closed. This doesn't make sense and could impact performance.
Issue 2: TreeEditPart resolves semantic elements which could be undesired behavior for some clients. Is there a way to avoid this?
The Outline View being created/refreshed/listening when it is not even visible is an Eclipse issue. See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=109299.
Reducing severity since we are dependent on platform Bug 109299

bug.short_desc: [Cleanup] 'New Example' wizard text not translated for runtime examples

long_desc.thetext:
The org.eclipse.gmf.examples.ui.pde plug-in has no translation fragments and, hence, does not have translations of any of the text that appears in the 'New Example' wizard, including the category name, example name, and example description.
Also, I wonder whether, as these examples demonstrate the run-time library, the plug-in ID shouldn't be 'org.eclipse.gmf.examples.runtime.ui.pde'?
This examples wizard is a generalized version of the *.runtime.examples.ui.pde plug-in.

There is no translations in Europa.
Since this is an IBM issue against the runtime, moving to runtime.

bug.short_desc: Display of variable contents on hover durining debugging

long_desc.thetext: Hovering over a variable during a debug session does not display the value of that variable. I was runing the script as 'Debug as PHP Executible'.
Fixed. The hover didn't work for files that are located in a non-root position of the project. Made a fix to the PHPDebugTextHover class.
Retested.

bug.short_desc: keyboard navigation to disabled controls in editors,views

long_desc.thetext:
Hello,
I wonder how I can keyboard-navigate to disabled controls in editors. While focussing disabled menu items is possible, I didn't succeed doing so for example in the PDE editor (disabled remove button in the runtime tab,...) Thus my JAWS 7.1 screenreader doesn't notify me about the disabled UI elements. In Inspect32 MSAA test tool, the disabled buttons or labels are in state 'unavailable, focusable'. But actually, I wonder how they are focusable, as I could imagine that if they were focusable, JAWS would read it. Does anyone of you have a comment on this? I couldn't find a similar bug report. Thanks in advance and best regards . marion
Tod, can you comment on this?

You cannot navigate to disable controls - this is an OS limitaton/feature.
You cannot give focus to a disabled control.

See: http://www.elver.org/hibernate/hibernateresources.html#Sharing+one+Session+between+Resources%2C+One+transaction+when+saving+multiple+resources http://www.elver.org/jpox/jpoxresources.html#Sharing+one+PersistenceManager+between+Resources%2C+One+transaction+when+saving+multiple+resources

bug.short_desc: [KeyBindings] Difference in Eclipse File Menu shortcuts between Linux and Windows Platforms

long_desc.thetext:
There seems to be a few differences in the shorcuts for some menu items in the File Menu of Eclipse.
"New Shift+Alt+N" on Redhat Linux while it is "New Alt+Shift+N" on Windows.
"Save All Shift+Ctrl+S" on Redhat Linux while it is "Save All Ctrl+Shift+S" on Windows
"Close All Shift+Ctrl+W" on Redhat Linux while it is "Close All Ctrl+Shift+W" on Windows
Although it is just that the Key sequence is different on the two platforms, it results in the failure of some TPTP AGR Functional Tests, that were originally developed on Windows, on Linux Platform. Not sure where the fix must be on the Eclipse UI side or the TPTP AGR side. Am initially putting it on Eclipse UI plate.

bug.short_desc: Modified Time-out Threshold for Each Command (ms) value not saved

long_desc.thetext:
AGR used: org.eclipse.tptp.test.auto-TPTP-4.2.1.zip Platform used: Redhat Desktop 4.0
The value of the field "Time-out Threshold for Each Command (millisecond)" on the behavior page of a TPTP AGR Test Suite for a test case can be changed, but the modified value is not retained when user returns to the test case after switching context (say to another test case), even on saving. This causes many of my tests that need a time out value greater than the default 30000ms to fail.
Please target to 4.4 since all non-blocking/critical defects will be deferred as decided in today's AG call.
Targeting to 4.4 as requested by Paul
There does not seem to be a workaround this problem. Can this bug be targetted for TPTP4.3 ? Changing priority to critical.

Govin,
Please try out the workarounds that I send you earlier. (i.e. using the upper/down arrow prior to saving the test suite and/or using multiple wait commands)
Let me know if either one will work for you. Thanks.

Created an attachment (id=53578) Patch
The modify listeners of a spinner behaves differently under Linux than on Windows. The attached patch uses a text box for the threshold value instead of a spinner.
I'm lowering the severity of this defect to major since there is a reasonable workaround for it. I will submit the patch as soon as CVS opens for TPTP 4.4.
Ali, please set the priority to P1 so this defect is addressed early in 4.4.
Fix checked into HEAD stream
Reporter: Please verify and close in preparation for shutting down the TPTP 4.4 release. Thanks.

bug.short_desc: [launcher] Invalid splash screen on update restart

long_desc.thetext:
build i1003
org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main#extractSplashFromJAR - if the splash screen already exists on disk, then the only time that we delete the file and re-extract it is if the -clean argument exists on the command-line.
This is problematic if the user did an update for a JAR'd bundle which provides the splash screen. In this case they will get the old splash on the restart.
From code inspection, still looks like a problem with the new launcher.jar.

This was fixed with bug 171701
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 171701 ***

bug.short_desc: [Preferences] consider a way of sharing preferences between workspaces

long_desc.thetext:
M2
As many people are now using multiple workspaces we need to consider a way to allow them to promote preferences to the configuration level.
I have written the start of a plug-in to do this although it is bare bones I will attack it to give us something to work from.
Here are some thoughts from DJ
how does the user (ui user) move a preference between scopes? how does the user (ui user) set a preference value once its in the config scope? is this function generally useable enough to put in the platform or should we just write a tool plug-in? how do we display config preferences to the user? what can we do so config preferences are included in search paths and plug-in developers have to change as little code as possible? should we treat it as an export opertation? (snapshot my prefs and move to the config scope) could probably do that with existing APIs and/or minimal code changes
There are currently no plans for the Platform team to work on this.

bug.short_desc: SC plugins need to be packaged as part of STP download

long_desc.thetext: Currently we're not building the SC plugins as part of the STP nightly build process. This needs to be fixed so integration builds includes this component.
Added SC Plugins to nightly build.
Added SC Plugins to nightly build.

bug.short_desc: feature request: visual indication of indexer status

long_desc.thetext:
Problem: Recently we've noticed a tendency for developers to use grep-style search rather that C/C++ search because they've seen cases where the indexer misses references.
Cause: Usually when the indexer doesn't have a reference it's due to project or workspace level settings.
Suggestion: Today there's no quick way for a user to see what's been indexed and what hasn't (the C++ Index view gives hints but isn't precise). A visual indication in the UI of indexer status for files and elements in the outline view would help build confidence in C/C++ search results by showing the user what will/won't be searched.
Concretely we're thinking that a warning marker in the problems view would call out unindexed elements and give the user a cue to fix the configuration problems.

Actually the C/C++ Index View is a direct dump of the index. If things are missing from this View, then they didn't get into the index.
We've had things like this in the past but it annoyed people. It would have to be optional, but it is a good idea.

bug.short_desc: -Dosgi.configuration.area=@none doesn't work

long_desc.thetext: What I expect for this feature is not creating the configuration or the org.eclipse.osgi directory at all so there wouldn't have any bundle being cached at all since my application will store the osgi bundle(s) in a different repository and since I cannot tell the different between what is being cached before and what I have in my repository before I start the Equinox. That is why I don't want the Equinox to cache my bundle(s). If this is not the right approach then is there a way to do what I want for the current release (3.2)
Need more information.

bug.short_desc: Rename in file does not preserve semantics

long_desc.thetext: Is this invoked by Ctrl 1 - Rename in file? Note that this is a quick assist and quick fix/assist not not semantic preserving, on purpose. They are more a coding tool like code assist to make local changes that can also be quickly undone. The rename refactoring is semantic preserving (we are experimenting in merging the two UIs, but at the moment they are still two different actions)

Yes it involves Ctrl+1. Still I disagree with your statement. People are used to have JDT do the right thing for them, and in this case it does not. Of course the compiler will report warnings, but still it is not a reason.
I think the root of the confusion comes from the name of this action ("rename") which is usually associated to refactoring. Maybe if the action led the user to think that this is a textual replace, then it would be less confusing.

bug.short_desc: icon descriptions in switch editor dialog (Ctrl+F6) are not available to screen readers

long_desc.thetext:
This is a screen reader accessibility issue for the icons that appear with the text in the switch editor dialog (Ctrl+F6).
There are two cases that come to mind for providing icon descriptions: 1. The icons represent different kinds of editors. Java, text, plugin.xml, etc. 2. The icon has been decorated. For example when a Java file contains warnings or errors the icon is decorated.
In both of these cases the editor icon is conveying information visually that also needs to be made available to a screen reader.
Tod, do we generally add accessibility for such things? We have these cases all over the case I imagine...

The only time you would do anything different is if there is information in the icon that is not in the text that makes the user unable to discern what is going on.
It could be argued that the warning or errors indicators are helpful but not having them does not block the user from finding out about them.

bug.short_desc: Package WSDM Tooling as tech preview

long_desc.thetext: done.
closing bug.

bug.short_desc: [find/replace] Regular expression extension in Find/Replace

long_desc.thetext: Can you provide a bit more details. I didn't get it yet.

This already works, e.g. the example in comment 2 can be done with:
replace: TYPESTR_$1.equals($2)
Now if we could just get /n to add newlines for the replace box...

bug.short_desc: ComposedAdapterFactory does not implement adaptNew()

long_desc.thetext: This prevents EcoreUtil.getRegisteredAdapter() from working with any CompositeAdapterFactory that can adapt the type passed as parameter.

It's designed to throw an exception so a change to that would be an enhancement. ;-)
I suppose we could just call adapt(Notifier, Object), which might not create a new adapter but rather return an existing one, or we could copy all the code in that method and it's helper method...
I can agree supporting adaptNew() could be seen as an enhancement, but doesn't the inability to use EcoreUtil.getRegisteredAdapter() with a CompositeAdapterFactory sound more like a defect?

Fred,
If you look at at the code, you'll see it's very clearly and intentionally throwing an exception and is even documented as throwing an exception. So changing this is an enhancement.
The call to adaptNew in the EcoreUtil method is intended as an optimization that avoids doing a lookup for an existing adapter first since the earlier part of the method has already looked for an existing adapter. So that too is intentional and not a defect.
The combination of the two reveals a new use case that was not considered and so now you'd like enhanced behavior so this will work nicely. We can do that in the 3.0 stream, and any client can provide their own override to work around any shortcomings...
I am definitely not asking for a fix before next release. Just raising the issue...
The enhancement is committed to CVS.

bug.short_desc: [1.5][compiler] Missing class casts in generated byte code for generic method

long_desc.thetext:
GenericType#doSomething()
eclipse===================== // Method descriptor #17 (Ljava/lang/Object;)V // Signature: (TE;)V // Stack: 3, Locals: 2 public void doSomething(Object e); 0 getstatic System.out : PrintStream [20] 3 aload_1 [e] 4 aload_1 [e] 5 invokeinterface Map$Entry.getValue() : Object [26] [nargs: 1] 10 invokeinterface Comparable.compareTo(Object) : int [32] [nargs: 2] 15 invokevirtual PrintStream.println(int) : void [38] 18 return
javac======================= // Method descriptor #15 (Ljava/lang/Object;)V // Signature: (TE;)V // Stack: 3, Locals: 2 public void doSomething(Object arg0); 0 getstatic System.out : PrintStream [2] 3 aload_1 4 checkcast Comparable [3] 7 aload_1 8 checkcast Map$Entry [4] 11 invokeinterface Map$Entry.getValue() : Object [5] [nargs: 1] 16 invokeinterface Comparable.compareTo(Object) : int [6] [nargs: 2] 21 invokevirtual PrintStream.println(int) : void [7] 24 return
also see bug 141289

Our support for inserted generic cast on multi-bound scenario is only dealing with fieldref/methodref receivers.
Extra cast should be on codegen of msgSend, when rcv type doesn't match expectation (secondary bound issue), whatever the receiver expression may be (not just field/method).
Should construct testcase with ternary or local or cast expression etc...
Created an attachment (id=52900) Proposed patch

Added GenericTypeTest#test1057
Released for 3.3M3. Fixed
Verified for 3.3 M3 using build I20061030-0010

bug.short_desc: [CommonNavigator] Should be possible to suppress ResourceLinkHelper selection by another LinkHelper

long_desc.thetext:
GMF allows to create Diagram Editor and we'd like to synchronize selection in this editor with the selection in "Project Explorer" view if "Link Open editors with content in navigator" button is pressed. GMF provides content of the diagram below the diagram file node in "Project Explorer", specific GMFLinkHelper class was created and registered. The probelm is: selection returned from GMFLinkHelper.findSelection(IEditorInput input) will be merged with one returned by ResourceLinkHelper.findSelection(IEditorInput input). As a result diagram file node will be selected in Project Explorer in any case.
Wed like to get rid of this selection we only have to select some sub-node(s) of diagram file returned by GMFLinkHelper. There should be a way to unregister ResourceLinkHelper for some particular cases. Looks like for now we can only work with custom IEditorInput implementations (not instanceof IFileEditorInput).

Looks like this question is a little bit more generic it is assumed that ILinkHelper will not change returned selection while working with Editor. So, Project Explorer provides the possibility to select a node in tree in accordance with Editor, but does not allow to change this selection while editing (changing selection in editor).
In other words, selection in Project Explorer will be the same while working with the same editor with "Link Open editors with content in navigator" switched on. In case of opposite synchronization it is possible to move selection in editor in accordance with selection in Project Explorer (e.g. select java method/attribute in Project Explorer -> corresponding line will be selected in editor).
So, the question is more generic: Should we allow to propagate selection of file structure parts into the Project Explorer by ILinkHelper or file-based selection is enough?

bug.short_desc: ExternalServerBehaviour for external servers on localhost which are already running

long_desc.thetext: The current setupLaunch behaviour of org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.core.internal.ExternalServerBehaviour is an issue in the following circumstances. We have a "remote"/external serverType defined. It is handy to be able to create a server based on this which is actually running on localhost, but is controlled outside of Eclispe/WTP. So the start behaviour is a no-op. But ExternalServerBehaviour.setupLaunch calls GenericServerBehaviour.setupLaunch which checks to see if the port is in use if the server is localhost, and displays an error message if it is. It should be possible to define a flag that overrides this behaviour i.e. allows external servers on localhost that are already running, doesn't check if the port is in use. The alternative to a flag is maybe a 'ExternalServerConnectBehaviour' that extends ExternalServerBehaviour (which is what we have done in the interm).
This is a valid request, but since there has been no resource to work on this I am adding the helpwanted keyword to request help from the community.

bug.short_desc: Equinox OSGi framework state file did not persist state file ASAP

long_desc.thetext:
When I started the Equinox OSGi framework with my osgi bundle(s) and then killed the process as soon as it started all my bundles. However, when I tried to re-launch the Equinox OSGi framework it did not boot any of my bundles. But, if I wait for a while (e.g. 20 second) before I killed the process then the re-launch will work.
I noticed in the failure scenario there are several files missing: configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/.bundledata.1 configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/.lazy.1 configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/.manager configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/.state.1

I believe this is working as designed - the saving is done periodically and not right away (just as you described :-)). It is possible that this was done to improve startup performance.
While there are instances where such behavior produces undesirable results, killing a running process before it had a chance to cache results is unlikely to be a supported scenario.

Oleg is correct. The framework only persists after a certain amount of inactivity. This is to prevent thrashing the file system as we are installing a large set of bundles. We also save when framework is shutdown. Other layers in the eclipse runtime have a similar policy (e.g. extension registry)
Can you instead force the framework to shutdown instead of killing it?
*** Bug 159814 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Can't the expected behavior be implemented using the framework hooks (BundleWatcher) to trigger an eager backup of the state files?
I tried to use the -console and then exit from the console and that didn't trigger the state information to be flushed out. Is this a correct behavior too?

(In reply to comment #5) > I tried to use the -console and then exit from the console and that didn't > trigger > the state information to be flushed out. Is this a correct behavior too?
Well, the exit command just does a System.exit(0) so that will not do the correct thing either. You should use the "close" command.
What is the proper OSGi way to enforce the state info are being flushed out to the disk?

Can you tell us more about how you are launching Equinox? Are you using EclipseStarter?
There is a property "eclipse.stateSaveDelayInterval" that you can set to make it save data more frequently. Currently it defaults to 30 seconds of no activity. The value is in milliseconds and the smallest allowed value is 1000 (1 second).
There currently is no way to force the state to save its data. You could write a framework hook that forces a save but currently the methods to save the data are private internal methods so you would have to use reflection to call them (I would prefer to avoid that).
There are a few ways to enforce the framework shutdown which will force the data to be flushed to cache.
- if you are using EclipseStarter you can call EclipseStarter.shutdown() - if you are in the framework you could call Bundle.stop() on the system bundle. This will spawn another thread and start the shutdown process of the framework.
We expect the framework to be shutdown properly to persist the data.

bug.short_desc: Provision of WSDL First Mode for STP by integration with WTP Editor

long_desc.thetext:
This bug is aimed at kicking off a conversation with the WTP guys to allow us to leverage the WSDL Editor in the STP. Areas that I feel we need to discuss are:
- Ability to extend the Editor to add additional views on WSDL and and additional editing abilities such as wizard based editing into the editor - Ability to break out the editor so it can differenciate between logical and physical wsdl. Logical WSDL will always require a very solid editor whereas newer generation of tools will allow the creation of physical components as derivations from the logical WSDL contract. It's important that our editor is capable of allowing users to edit and manage logical contract material and to treat physical as being generated as opposed to allowing users edit this manually. - Provide additional hooks to allow additional (possibly non-standard) WSDL entities be edited within the editor in a way where the look and feel will be identical to editing any other part of the WSDL.

Adding Chris to CC.
Chris can you please comment on these requirements for the WTP planning call? Adrian can provide more info if needed.

Additional suggestions: WTP contains a number of internal APIs that are really of general use, e.g. in the area of creating wizards. As an example, the following internal classes are useful for creating new project wizards and save code duplication in that area, the rely on the WST datamodel that is used within the wizards. It would be very useful if these classes could be made public.
org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.internal.datamodel.ui.DataModelWizardPage - this one binds a WTP datamodel to the widgets on the screen, very handy...
org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.internal.operations.IProjectCreationPropertiesNew - provides common constants for an embedded new project creation datamodel org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.internal.operations.ProjectCreationDataModelProviderNew - can create a data model for a new project org.eclipse.wst.common.frameworks.internal.ui.NewProjectGroup - creates a new project widget group in the wizard (name, location etc)
Especially the DataModelWizardPage is really a timesaver if you are using the wst IDataModel class (which is public already) to hold your wizard data, since it can automatically synchronize the wizard widgets with your model. I think this class could be used in any place that uses the WTP datamodel.
I found the project classes very useful as it could save you from having to duplicate the code to create a new project. If these ones are made public, creating a new project wizard that looks right is becomes very simple.
Adding craig to CC

Naci, thanks for adding Craig to the cc. list. The WSDL editor is his baby.
Adrian, would you please elaborate a bit on your second requirement? I don't think I understand what you mean by "logical" and "physical" WSDL. Sometimes the former term is associated with portType/interface-only WSDL (ie. WSDL without bindings). Some of the other extensibility you've asked for is available, though it may not be public API yet. Craig owns the gory details.

Hi Chris,
In terms of a logical vs. physical split, everything up to and including the porttype is considered the logical part of the WSDL contract. Physical stuff (bindings & transports) tend to have the requirement that when you go to deploy the WSDL, these could possibly change, and we'd like to have the control that the user could defer chosing what the physical parts of the WSDL needs to be. So I guess we'd like to be able to hide away the physical bits of the WSDL editor so that the STP could extend at that point to provide a different mechansim to create the physical entities.
I hope this makes sense, if you like, we can arrange a time and have a chat to discuss this in more detail.

Thanks for kicking of the discussion. David's request in comment #2 deserves a new bug. I've tried to answer your WSDL editor feature requests one at a time below. It'd be great to get some mocked-up screen shots to paint the picture more clearly. It'll probably be more efficient to discuss your requirements verbally just to get started on these issues and get an understanding of time lines etc. I'd be happy to take some time to chat with you and your team members to discuss in more detail.
- Ability to extend the Editor to add additional views on WSDL and and additional editing abilities such as wizard based editing into the editor
I'm not sure what 'wizard base editing' means but we do have experimental support for providing alternative views.
- Ability to break out the editor so it can differenciate between logical and physical wsdl...
It would be fairly easy to add a filter to the WSDL editor so that only the interface content is shown. I'm not sure what you mean by 'break out'.
- Provide additional hooks to allow additional (possibly non-standard) WSDL entities be edited within the editor in a way where the look and feel will be identical to editing any other part of the WSDL.
Hmm.. I think it'd be good to get some examples here. We do support editing of Extension elements in the properties sheet's 'Extension' tab. If there were non standard bits of WSDL that needed to be shown in the main editor editor we'd need to understand where/how you'd want to display these.

The stack trace matches, and the exception is occuring on the same line of code, as documented in bug 159458. As Kathy wrote in bug 159458 comment 1, the problem can occur "if the user (e.g.) deletes the runtime, deletes the entire server adapter plugins, or is using a workspace from another product that has a different server adapter".
I'm not sure if any of these situations apply to the history of your workspace, however, a quick test is to start up WTP on a fresh workspace, target Apache Tomcat, and try the scenario again.

bug.short_desc: Support specifing no-ops for GenericServer framework server start/stop configurations

long_desc.thetext:
The GenericServer framework start/stop configurations cannot be no-ops i.e. they have to do something. It is handy to be able to specify an external server, but control it outside of Eclipse (so that e.g. it can be left running between debug sessions) and simply connect to it on server start. Currently, an external commandline must be specified that gets executed in the working directory e.g.
<start> <workingDirectory>${cc.server.root.directory}/Server/jboss-4.0.2/bin</workingDirectory> <debugPort>7000</debugPort> <external os="windows xp">cmd</external> </start>
But this means that a console shows this exec, which looks strange for a user, when really what is required is a no-op i.e. "starting" a remote/external server (which cannot be started remotely for whatever reason, or is already running) is really just a case of connecting, checking to see if it is running.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 156508 ***
This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP bugs which are in the resolved state without an appropriate targeted version. If you feel this bug was closed inappropriately, please reopen.

bug.short_desc: [Help][Context] Provide a public way to get the help id of a control

long_desc.thetext:
What you need to do instead is set the focus appropriately upon page activation so that after you click next, the focus is set on one of the fields in the new page. This is not only useful for context help but also for usability so that users can start typing right away or tab through the page.
For an example, see File -> New -> Project. Select General -> Project and click Next. Notice how the focus is automatically set on the Project name field and you can start typing right away. Doing this should solve your problem.

I have seen examples where setting the focus to a particular control in an editor has caused the proper help to be displayed, but I haven't seen an example for a wizard. An example was given in the last update to this defect about the New Project wizard. It's true that it does set focus to a particular control and that the proper help is always displayed as the user traverses the wizard pages. However, I do not think this has anything to do with the fact that focus was set to a control.
To test my theory, I imported the plug-in that defines the New Project wizard, org.eclipse.ui.ide, into my workspace. In the method that sets the focus to a control, WizardNewProjectCreationPage.setVisible(), I commented out the line that calls setFocus(). I launched a runtime workbench and opened the New Project wizard. On the first page I noticed the text control at the top did not have focus (because of my change). I pressed F1, the help opened and displayed the proper text. I pressed Next to move to the next page and the help changed to the help for the new page. I went back to the previous page and again the help changed. This is exactly how I would expect it to work and it was done without setting focus to a control. Also note that the second page of this wizard never explicitly sets focus to a control like the first page does and it also works.
Perhaps this strategy works for editors, but I'm not convinced it does for wizards. I think the reason the New Project wizard works is a help id is assigned to the top most Composite of each page. When I do this in my wizard, everything works too. It's not as straight forward for me tho because, as I described in my initial comment in this defect, I am hosting pages that others define. I am wrapping the Composite of each client page in a ScrolledComposite. I think in order to get the help to update properly I need to extract the help id from the client composite and set it in the scrolled composite.
I will attach a plug-in to this defect that simulates the design of my wizard. It contributes a wizard with two pages. I'm using the help ids from the import/export wizards just as an example. Maybe you can use it to prove me wrong. :) If not, does my original request to provide public access to WorkbenchHelpSystem.HELP_KEY now make sense?
Created an attachment (id=54331) Example wizard
WorkbenchHelpSystem is defined in org.eclipse.ui.workbench. Reassigning to Platform UI for consideration.

bug.short_desc: Closing browser widget causes JVM crash.

long_desc.thetext:
I'm part of the IBM Support Assistant (ISA) team and we are running on RCP using its SWT browser widget. One of our pages provides links to help IBM customers. When a user clicks on a link, another browser widget pops up, displaying the link page.
The bug occurs when the link URL is: http://www-306.ibm.com/software/support/rss/websphere/171.xml?rss=s171&ca=rsswebsphere
When a user clicks on that link, the behavior becomes inconsistent. Sometimes, the new popup window will display that contents of that link as expected. Then, when you close the popup window, the JVM crashes, and so does ISA. Othertimes, it will crash while loading the popup window. One time, I was able to load and close the popup window with seemingly no error. But when I tried to load another link in another popup, JVM crashed then. The JVM never crashes when any of the other .html, .wss, or .jsp links are clicked.
I forgot to add that I tested this in RAD as well. When I first tested it on RAD 6.0.0.1, the JVM crashed also (and so did RAD). But then I upgraded to the latest RAD 6.0.1 and can't reproduce it.
I can reproduce this problem in the latest swt.
I can't reproduce this now in any of the workspaces that used to show the crash. Has the page changed? Are you still able to make it happen?

I can still reproduct Eclipse bug 159748. To reproduce, open RAD, and open the web browser within RAD. Point the web browser to the URL specified in the bug. Close the web browser. Now, reopen the web browser and try to go to www.yahoo.com. JVM crashes.

bug.short_desc: Expand all comments on bugzilla editor takes too much time

long_desc.thetext:
In bugzilla editor, if you click on "+" sign to expand all comments, it takes too long if there are many comments.

bug.short_desc: MAX: Better visualization of complex data types

long_desc.thetext: Managed Agent Explorer needs to handle complex data types. This includes CompositeData, TabularData and arrays of OpenTypes. It should also knew who to display complex data types in a meaningful way to the user.

An additional requirement is the for the MAX to display complex types properly and allow the entry of individual elements of a complex type in a visually non-confusing manner for operation parameters, property values and returned values.
Removing target because it has not been approved by PMC yet for inclusion in the 4.4 plan. Adding sizing from description document.

Here are more details for the implementation:
If a parameter or property has a type of org.w3c.Element, then the data that comes into it is checked for well-formedness before being passed to the agent. This means that the String value that comes in from the UI must be deserialized into a XML document and if no errors are thrown the data is passed to the agent. If there is a problem this must be displayed to the user.
This may be reused in the Test Project for our datapool editor. Let me when you start work on this feature so we can be involved.

bug.short_desc: Eclipse crashes (and takes down the X server) when opening an unformatted XML file

long_desc.thetext:
I have some XML files which are unformatted. ie.. all the data is on ONE line, except for the <?xml version="1.0"?> line of course. Some of these files are upwards of 33K in size or bigger.
When I open the file up in eclipse to edit it, eclipse crashes HARD and takes the X server down with it. I have nothing in my X server logs leading to what the issue is, nothing in my kernel log either, nor in the eclipse .metadata/.log file pertaining to the crash (or anywhere NEAR the time of the crash)
If I format the XML (using xmllint --format) and load that file into eclipse, everything is fine and eclipse is happy and doesn't do anything "bad".
My OS details..
Fedora Core 5 x86_64 Athlong 64 3200+ 2GB DDR 400 Ram Nvidia GF4200 128MB (nvidia drivers version 8774) This occurs under both the 64bit Sun JVM 1.5.0_07 AND the 32bit JVM 1.5.0_08. (switched JVMs and eclipse builds in hopes of less memory usage..)
This is recreatable EVERY time..
This looks similar to bug 108806. That bug was fixed in wtp 1.0.1 though, so it should be fixed in wtp 1.5. Could you attach some example xmls that crash wtp?

My guess this is not so much an xml editor issue, as and SWT StyleText issue. See, for example, bug 108813.
If you have the time/ability, I'd suggest a "pure" SWT test, similar to those attached to 108813, or, using them as the starting point, to see what effect very long lines have.
It'll be hard for us to do this work ourselves, as I know of no one handy with a 64 bit machine, much less one with Fedora.
But, do please attach a sample file if you can.

I've tried re-creating the error, but have upgraded nvidia drivers since then and gone to FC6. it no longer crashes X, but takes a REALLY REALLY REALLY REALLY long time to render and ends up creating this nice black blob of overlayed text until I run xmllint --format on the xml file.
And this happened with the 32 bit JVM as well (just host OS was x86_64)

Updating OS to ALL since we have observed the same poor performance / lockup behavior on Windows as well as the original Linux-GTK post.
Another way to incite the failure is: Create a very large wsdl file that is all written on two lines. Run the formatter over it it locks up the workbench.
We did some investigation in January and one of our devs noted the following in that version of the source: "This is a two part issue:
#1. The actions in the StructuredTextEditor are TextOperationAction instances, by default the run method runs these operations on the UI thread. #2. There is a major scalability issue with the XML formatter. We will need to profile the problem.
The issue starts in the FORMAT_DOCUMENT case in the StructuredTextViewer#doOperation(int) method. This is line 424 in the current source."
Hopefully this additional information will raise the priority of this issue as the formatter really isn't usable for large, poorly formatted documents as it stands.
Amy, I'm sure some of this issues haven't gone away, but can you assess if they have improved with some of the formatter fixes made last release? Or, can this bug be a dup of another?

The performance of formatting poorly formatted documents was improved in WTP 1.5.3 see bug 136902.
Todd, what build of WTP are you guys using? If you are formatting a large number of files, it might be more useful to use our background formatter instead. To use, select the files to be formatted in the project explorer and then do Source -> Format. If you do choose to use this path, I'd advise not having the files open in an editor while background formatting. We have had some issues surface with that scenario.
Edward, when you open your wsdl file, are you opening it on the design page or the source page? I have noticed the wsdl editor can be pretty slow when opening a poorly formatted file on the source page, but opening the same file on the design page is quicker. It's very possible it has to do with bug 108813 like David mentioned.

Our latest issues are with WTP 2.0. The performance of the XML editor on larger files is very poor in our tests. That includes both time to open and edit as well as formatting, whether the file is already well-formatted or not.

I know how valuable a good test case is so I've attached an XML file that demonstrates the issues. Just open it in the editor and note the time and memory it takes or reformat it and note the time and memory it takes and I believe you'll see the issue. In case anyone is curious, this is a real-world example that came in from one of our users, and is one example of many. I didn't simply try to make up a big file that causes problems for y'all. :-)

bug.short_desc: 2007 Connectathon PDC 11311 Test Case Exact Name Search

long_desc.thetext: Test case 11311 covers an exact name search by the Patient Demographics Consumer. Several ADT messages are sent to the Patient Demographics Supplier. Then, the PD Consumer sends a query. The consumer is expected to query by exact patient name: PID.5.1 = MOORE PID.5.2 = CHIP other query keys should be present. If populated, field RCP-2 should contain the value 10^RD or a higher number. This will allow a response with all records. There are later tests for limiting the number of records in a response. QPD-1 (Message Query Name) is a field that the Supplier needs to be able to configure on a site specific basis. For these tests, set the value to QRY_PDQ_1001^Query By Name^IHEDEMO
Plugin & Bridge passed
All known OHF users have passed their MESA tests. Closed.
closing

bug.short_desc: ConcurrentModificationException during ResourceManager.commit()

long_desc.thetext:
When processing a commit() the ChangeDescription of the transaction is compressed by EMF. This can eventually lead to demand loading of eContainer() objects. The thread that receives the demand loaded object can tries to modify the model and the ChangeDescription respectively. The result is a ConcurrentModificationException.
Solution: Disable demand loading during commit()
Committed to CVS
Fixed in M200610041414

bug.short_desc: 2007 Connectathon PDC 11365 Test Case Continuation Test 1

long_desc.thetext: Test 11365 is a test of the HL7 Continuation Protocol. In this test, a Patient Demographics Consumer needs to configure their request with a specific limit and successfully process the response from the PD Supplier. PID.5.1 = MOO* No other query keys should be present. Field RCP-2 should contain the value 1^RD to indicate one record per response. QPD-1 (Message Query Name) is a field that the Supplier needs to be able to configure on a site specific basis. For these tests, set the value to QRY_PDQ_1001^Query By Name^IHEDEMO The field QPD-8 should have the value ^^^&1.3.6.1.4.1.21367.2005.1.1&ISO to specify that domain in the response or can be left empty. The evaluation script will examine your query, but will not examine the intermediate and subsequent queries sent by your system. If you do not send the proper continuation data, the MESA server will not respond and will log information in the MESA log messages.
Plugin & Bridge passed
All known OHF users have passed their MESA tests. Closed.
closing
