bug.short_desc: [DataBinding] update policies need to be implemented

long_desc.thetext: defaults to POLICY_AUTOMATIC, but we need to implement POLICY_EXPLICIT as well.

Dave and Boris, I'm implementing this and have a question about the validation policy. I'm trying to determine what this should apply to. I started thinking it should be all validation but that doesn't feel right now.
What I currently have is if the model policy is EXPLICIT and the validate policy is AUTOMATIC then all validation is ran for every target change. But what I'm now thinking is if the model policy is EXPLICIT and the validate policy is EXPLICIT then all validation and conversion should be run *except* for business validation. This would allow for simple validation of the target but then allows for deferring costly validation until a copy to the model or an explicit call to validate the target has been made (I've added a method to Binding to do this). If this is the way to go it seems like it would make sense to change the method in BindSpec to businessValidatePolicy from validatePolicy.
This seems to satisfy the 2 use cases that I know of for policies: 1. In a dialog defer copying to the model until the user applies the dialog changes but provide a means to validate the target on change (model EXPLICIT, validate AUTOMATIC). 2. If validation is expensive it can be deferred until a copy to the model or an explicit call to validate the target occurs (model EXPLICIT, validate EXPLICIT).

How about an update policy per binding, but a validation policy per validator?
I'm thinking of something like BindSpec.addValidator(int validationTime, IValidator validator) where validationTime might be one of the constants defined for BindingListener. Apart from being flexible, this has the advantage that Binding implementations (like ListBinding) can refuse to handle certain validationTime values if they don't make sense. You could also define two validators for the same validationTime, which would make validators more reusable.

Are you saying we remove PIPELINE_AFTER_VALIDATE and PIPELINE_AFTER_BUSINESS_VALIDATE and register for the other phases like PIPELINE_AFTER_GET for validation?
The only issue I'm seeing is what would an EXPLICIT model update policy mean? Does it mean just run all validation down to PIPELINE_AFTER_CONVERT on every change? If so we might need another phase to mean before changing the model.

(In reply to comment #3)
This was just an idea and I wanted to see what you think about it. Yes, the PIPELINE_*_VALIDATE constants would disappear, and it seems that we would need another phase. I would suggest getting rid of the PIPELINE_ prefix at the same time.
Instead of EXPLICIT, we could let clients specify at which phase to stop when processing a change event.

(In reply to comment #4) > This was just an idea and I wanted to see what you think about it. Yes, the > PIPELINE_*_VALIDATE constants would disappear, and it seems that we would need > another phase. I would suggest getting rid of the PIPELINE_ prefix at the same > time.
Sounds good.
> Instead of EXPLICIT, we could let clients specify at which phase to stop when > processing a change event.
I was kind of thinking this as well. I'll try it out.

Unfortunately I'm too far from the current code to understand clearly why PIPELINE_AFTER_VALIDATE no longer makes sense. If it's not too much trouble, I'd appreciate understanding that logic.
On the other hand, I'd pretty strongly recommend keeping the PIPELINE_ prefix unless there's a compelling reason to remove it. I often find myself using that prefix and Eclipse's autocomplete to remember the exact names of the various PIPELINE_ constants.

(In reply to comment #6) > Unfortunately I'm too far from the current code to understand clearly why > PIPELINE_AFTER_VALIDATE no longer makes sense. If it's not too much trouble, > I'd appreciate understanding that logic.
The removal of PIPELINE_AFTER_VALIDATE and PIPELINE_AFTER_BUSINESS_VALIDATE won't be removing any functionality... I don't think. Basically what is being proposed is to be able to add validators that will validate after the pipeline event. So instead of having a phase for validation the consumer will register validators to run at the times of PIPELINE_AFTER_GET, PIPELINE_AFTER_CONVERT, and a phase yet to be named (PIPELINE_BEFORE_CHANGE ???). So to run validation for what is now PIPELINE_AFTER_VALIDATE the consumer will just register a validator for PIPELINE_AFTER_GET. The only thing I'm not sure of is if this will have an effect on consumers that are registering binding listeners and if they would want to be notified before and/or after validation is ran at these stages.
> On the other hand, I'd pretty strongly recommend keeping the PIPELINE_ prefix > unless there's a compelling reason to remove it. I often find myself using > that prefix and Eclipse's autocomplete to remember the exact names of the > various PIPELINE_ constants.
I don't feel strongly either way on this one. I'll let you two duke it out. :)

I have this implemented for ValueBinding and wanted to run some of the changes by you:
* the PIPELINE_* constants that referred to validation are gone * the get/set validation methods are gone from BindSpec * there are now PIPELINE_BEFORE_VALIDATE and PIPELINE_AFTER_VALIDATE phases * when binding events fire 2 will be fired for each position one before validation and one after except for PIPELINE_AFTER_CHANGE (no need to validate after the change has occurred). This is available in BindingEvent.validationPosition. * the events are now: * PIPELINE_AFTER_GET * PIPELINE_AFTER_CONVERT * PIPELINE_BEFORE_CHANGE * PIPELINE_AFTER_CHANGE * PIPELINE_BEFORE_CHANGE is to allow for deferring of "expensive" validation and nothing more. In all other use cases it is superfluous because validators can be registered for PIPELINE_AFTER_CONVERT. * Added Binding.validateTarget(int pipelinePosition) to invoke validation manually. This just runs the normal update and stops at the provided position. It needs to be renamed because it will copy to the model if asked. * Added BindSpec.addTargetValidator(int pipelinePosition, IValidator validator) * Added BindSpec.getTargetValidators(int pipelinePosition) * Added BindSpec.addModelValidator(int pipelinePosition, IValidator validator) (this adds validation to copy to target operations) * Added BindSpec.getModelValidators(int pipelinePosition) * Added BindSpec.setTargetValidatePosition(Integer pipelinePosition) * For ValueBinding when the model update policy is EXPLICIT and the consumer doesn't specify a target validate position the default is PIPELINE_AFTER_CONVERT.
I'm probably going to rework some of the naming before I check it in (e.g. Binding.validateTarget(...) and BindSpec.setTargetValidatePosition(...)). I need to implement the changes for ListBinding as well. So far I like it.

Is BindingListener still necessary?
It seems to me that this new validation story is flexible enough so that we don't need BindingListener for validation purposes anymore. IIRC, the only remaining use case is being notified about changes to the model. Could we get rid of BindingListener by adding a listener that is notified after the model has been changed successfully? This would simplify the API quite a bit.

One other thing that I had on my mind was if the pipeline position should be made available to the validator. Having fine grained validators is nice but if we made the position available a validation algorithm could be encapsulated in one validator.

(In reply to comment #9) > IIRC, the only > remaining use case is being notified about changes to the model.
Out of curiosity how would this be used? Do you know of a use case off the top of your head when someone needs to know that the binding changed the model?

> Out of curiosity how would this be used? Do you know of a use case off the top > of your head when someone needs to know that the binding changed the model?
I believe it had to do with persistence. Dave?

To keep the nofication for copy how about we leave BindingListener and just provide notifications after validation for each position and then also for PIPELINE_AFTER_CHANGE? If we keep the API we'll be leaving opportunities for logging, debugging, etc.

(In reply to comment #12) > > Out of curiosity how would this be used? Do you know of a use case off the top > > of your head when someone needs to know that the binding changed the model? > > I believe it had to do with persistence. Dave? >
hibernateSession.save(changedObject)

(In reply to comment #10) > One other thing that I had on my mind was if the pipeline position should be > made available to the validator. Having fine grained validators is nice but if > we made the position available a validation algorithm could be encapsulated in > one validator. >
Yes!

(In reply to comment #13) > To keep the nofication for copy how about we leave BindingListener and just > provide notifications after validation for each position and then also for > PIPELINE_AFTER_CHANGE? If we keep the API we'll be leaving opportunities for > logging, debugging, etc. >
I agree here too.

Here's what I'm now thinking: 1. Change IBindingListener to just be a listener and not participate in validation. This will give the hook to be able to persist objects on change. 2. Create IPipelineValidator. This will have validate(Object value, int pipelinePosition). 3. Create bindSpec.addTargetValidator(IPipelineValidator) to register the validator. 4. Leave IValidator alone.
IPipelineValidator will be pretty close to what IBindingListener is today which makes me almost want to just leave things as they are. But by having this API it makes a pipeline validation algorithm a first class citizen. It also prohibits more than one to be registered and allows for this to be defined at the BindSpec level which could lead to reusable BindSpecs.
What do you think?

(In reply to comment #17) > 3. Create bindSpec.addTargetValidator(IPipelineValidator) to register the > validator.
Make that setTargetValidator and there will also be setModelValidator. It would probably also be good to provide the direction to the validator so that target and model could be rolled into one.

(In reply to comment #17) > Here's what I'm now thinking: > 1. Change IBindingListener to just be a listener and not participate in > validation. This will give the hook to be able to persist objects on change. > 2. Create IPipelineValidator. This will have validate(Object value, int > pipelinePosition). > 3. Create bindSpec.addTargetValidator(IPipelineValidator) to register the > validator. > 4. Leave IValidator alone. > > IPipelineValidator will be pretty close to what IBindingListener is today which > makes me almost want to just leave things as they are. But by having this API > it makes a pipeline validation algorithm a first class citizen. It also > prohibits more than one to be registered and allows for this to be defined at > the BindSpec level which could lead to reusable BindSpecs. > > What do you think? >
I agree with the sentiment but I think this doesn't go far enough.
I agree with you that right now we have two ways to do validation: the binding event listener and the validators and that these need to be merged.
I'd like to look at merging them entirely so that one or the other goes away completely. In other words, I'd like to see validators simply be binding event listeners and get rid of our whole current concept of a validator.
Either that, or make the validator framework powerful enough that you can validate anywhere in the pipeline, and then do away with the pipeline.
Both the validator framework and the binding listener framework let you listen to events in the pipeline and do something. Maybe they should be merged into the same thing? Do we really have a need for both as separate, distinct APIs?
If we can have a single clean API that can do both, this part of Data Binding will be easier to learn since folks won't have to ask the question, "when do I use which part of the API?"

I'd be fine with IPipelineValidator becoming IValidator. We could then invoke the validator again after change and you'd have your notification.
The other option I see is changing validators to act as filters (converters could also be filters). You add them to the process as it goes through the pipeline each filter is invoked when requested. But the problem with this sort of API then becomes "how do I use the API"? Having one API for multiple tasks can make it harder on the consumer as it's clean for us but the usage can be unclear.
I'd personally rather keep validators as key players in this process. When people come to a data binding solution they look for how validation and conversion are handled and genericising either API would make the core concepts harder to grasp. Plus by having the type IValidator the consumer is declaring their intent that this class is to validate the data. If it was generic we'd lose some of the semantic meaning that we get from the interface. For a long while I didn't understand what IBindingListener was even meant to do and received questions from other developers along the same lines as my confusion.
IMHO if we're looking to make this "easier to learn" I think that we need to keep IValidator, but pass the copyType and pipelinePosition, and fire validation after change as well.
*** Bug 169988 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

(In reply to comment #20) > IMHO if we're looking to make this "easier to learn" I think that we need to > keep IValidator, but pass the copyType and pipelinePosition, and fire > validation after change as well.
Dave and/or Boris, do you have a preference on which one to keep?

re: comment 22
I'd have to spike both APIs and see which I like. It's hard to say without seeing it.

Sorry, but I don't like either of the two very much. Validators should be stateless, so why is it important to pass the pipeline phase to them rather than adding them to the BindSpec and at that time setting the phase to which the validator applies?
Boris, what ya thinkin'? :)

(In reply to comment #25) > By expanding the API slightly we can handle both use cases and get rid of the > listener API.
I'm on board. I like the flexibility of the new API. I like that we can get rid of BindingEvent because it now becomes redundant.
I'm not sure I like calling everything a "validator" though, because folks will use this kind of like Display.addFilter in SWT.
Which makes me wonder if addFilter() is a better name than addValidtor(). It carries the same idea as validators, but also carries the idea that you can use it for more than validation, similar to the SWT API.

I eluded to filters in comment 20 as well. We could do it and I'm becoming more comfortable with it. Since we're talking about adding this ability to ever stage I guess validation becomes a little less of a structured process. So I'd be onboard with a filter if everyone else is.

Spoke with Boris and came to the following: * still provide IConvert and IValidator as is * replace listeners with filters * TODO determine if conversion can occur in filter as well
By keeping converts and validators as is it's making the normal use cases simple. Filtering will then be an advanced API.
Dave, you cool with this? I am.

(In reply to comment #30) > Spoke with Boris and came to the following: > * still provide IConvert and IValidator as is > * replace listeners with filters > * TODO determine if conversion can occur in filter as well > > By keeping converts and validators as is it's making the normal use cases > simple. Filtering will then be an advanced API. > > Dave, you cool with this? I am.
I don't prefer it. I'd like to eat our own dog food more than this.
Like maybe a Validator is just another kind of IObservableValue. Same for a Converter. Binding listeners are just another IObservableValue inserted into the chain.

(In reply to comment #31) > > By keeping converts and validators as is it's making the normal use cases > > simple. Filtering will then be an advanced API.
Yes, this is exactly where I'm coming from.
> Like maybe a Validator is just another kind of IObservableValue. Same for a > Converter. Binding listeners are just another IObservableValue inserted into > the chain.
I don't understand. Could you explain how this would look like?

After speaking with Boris I'm just going to implement the changes for policies and multiple validators. I'm going to leave binding listeners alone for the time being so that I can make progress. But we need to decide soon on how we want listeners/filters implemented. M5 is coming up quickly...
Reopening to make partial validation behave like the other positions.
Partial validation is now a part of the pipeline and not a separate event (API wise). Validators can be registered at the BindingEvent.PIPELINE_VALUE_CHANGING pipeline position.
VERIFIED in I20070206-0010.

bug.short_desc: 2007 Connectathon PIXS 10512 Test Case PIX Patient Feed A04

long_desc.thetext: Test case 10512 covers PIX Patient Feed and the ADT^A04 message. These behaviors are tested: Patient Identity Source formulates an A04 message with the proper content Patient Identify Source can send a patient ID (PID-3) in three different configurations. These may be runtime configurations required by a combination of actors. The assigning authority shall have these values listed below. Each value represents the same concept: Test A: HIMS2005 Test B: HIMS2005&1.3.6.1.4.1.21367.2005.1.1&ISO Test C: &1.3.6.1.4.1.21367.2005.1.1&ISO The nominal patient name is EPSILON^ELLIE. The evaluation script will expect specific values in an A04 message that you create. Look at the example HL7 message that is mentioned by the test script; then configure your Patient Identification Source to fill in the proper values. For some fields such as Patient ID List (PID-3), you will obviously fill in a value that is generated by your system. For other fields such as Patient Name (PID-5), the evaluation script will expect the exact value. This test is constructed of two tests. In the first test (10512), the Patient ID Source sends the A04 message with an assigning authority of ADT1. In the second test, the Patient ID sends the A04 message with an assigning authority of &1.3.6.1.4.1.21367.2005.1.1&ISO.
Plugin & Bridge passed
All known OHF users have passed their MESA tests. Closed.
closing

bug.short_desc: Reproducible Feature Manifest Editor sequence causes JVM hotspot error

long_desc.thetext:
I have an installation of Eclipse 3.2.0 SDK that was updated to 3.2.1. I have found a reproducible (so on any new workspace) JVM crash that terminates eclipse leaving a hotspot dump. I'm attaching the last one I got.
Do the following: Open eclipse 3.2.1, new workspace In java perspective (so I never switched), new feature project, fill in values in the wizard for all fields (not library), click finish (no plugins in feature). Do not switch to PDE perspective. Open feature manifest (if not already). Click in ID field at the end of the text value. Dirty field (space, backspace) TAB to next field, dirty again (space, backspace) Repeat through provider field (notice UI refresh/flash when tabbing out of the third field) After the cursor is left at the end of the provider field, click the Information tab. JVM terminates.
Plug-ins installed include, but not limited to, subclipse, mylar.
A coworked tried it on 3.2.0 and got no crash (different machine, though).

Created an attachment (id=51422) hotspot dump file
JVM hotspot dump file upon crash
When you restart Eclipse, is there anything in the error log by chance?
nope, nothing, only the workspace-crash-detected entry.
Do you see any jvm core dump logs in the root of your Eclipse directory?
I attached it already (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=51422&action=view)
After consulting with Dejan, I am moving this big to the SWT team for investigation.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 150782 ***

bug.short_desc: [msic] Javadoc View formats version tag as "@version", not "Version:"

long_desc.thetext:
When processing Javadoc comments for classes, the Javadoc View formats some tags properly, e.g. displaying the 'author' tag as "Author:" in boldface. However, the 'version' tag is displayed as "@version" rather than "Version:".
To reproduce:
1. Create any Java class 2. Write a Javadoc comment for the class, containing various tags (I've tried @author, @see and @version) 3. Activate Javadoc view: the 'author' and 'see' tags are formatted correctly but the 'version' tag is not.
Move to JDT/UI.

bug.short_desc: [EditorMgmt] EditorRegistry throws out external editors when reading when importing
bundle org.eclipse.equinox.cm fails to start on OSGi Min/RM

long_desc.thetext:
We had the bundle org.eclipse.equinox.cm_3.2.0.200609272246.jar built from the Eclipse project org.eclipse.equinox.cm, then tried to start it on the stand-alone Equinox 3.2.1 running on J9 (version 2.2) against JCL RM (J9 -jcl:rm), and OSGiMin 11 implementation. The bundle org.eclipse.equinox.cm failed to start with the following exception:
org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Exception in org.eclipse.equinox.cm.internal .Activator.start() of bundle org.eclipse.equinox.cm. at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl.startActiv ator(BundleContextImpl.java:1010) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl.start(Bund leContextImpl.java:966) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleHost.startWorker(Bundl eHost.java:317) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.AbstractBundle.start(Abstrac tBundle.java:256) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkCommandProvider._st art(FrameworkCommandProvider.java:239) at java.lang.reflect.AccessibleObject.invokeV(AccessibleObject.java:205)
at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:253) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkCommandInterpreter. execute(FrameworkCommandInterpreter.java:145) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkConsole.docommand(F rameworkConsole.java:293) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkConsole.console(Fra meworkConsole.java:278) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkConsole.run(Framewo rkConsole.java:213) at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:719) Nested Exception: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: java.text.DateFormat at org.eclipse.equinox.cm.internal.LogTracker.<init>(LogTracker.java:48)
at org.eclipse.equinox.cm.internal.Activator.start(Activator.java:26) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl$2.run(Bund leContextImpl.java:991) ---------
Note that the Equinox 3.2 had the similar problem described in bug 149892 (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=149892), which has been fixed in Equinox 3.2.1.

Looking at the source it seems that org.eclipse.equinox.cm is built against the OSGi Foundation Execution Environment, rather than the OSGi Minimum Execution Environment. This is truly unfortunate.
I took a quick look and I see the following classes are used, which are not available in the OSGi Minimum Execution Environment:
- DateFormat - HashMap - LinkedList - TreeMap - TreeSet
Also:
- The File method listFiles() is not defined.
In the past I've survived without DateFormat by using Calendar, but of course locale specific formatting is therefore not possible, or at least a lot harder. This is clearly not a case where date/time formatting justifies using the large Execution Environment.
All uses of HashMap can be replaced with Hashtable. If you've typed your declarations to the Map interface then this should be an easy fix.
Regarding LinkedList, TreeMap and TreeSet, I would suggest using some Collection available in the Minimum Execution Environment, or else implement your own. Again, not really something that justifies the larger Execution Environment.
This might not be an exhustive list of issues.

Wow, it seems that the ee.minimum.jar that I have been compiling against was dated 5/26/2005, and seems to be the OSGi Minimum 1.0. Thanks to John W Ross for pointing out the error of my ways.
So, now that I'm using the ee.minimum.jar for OSGi Minimum 1.1 I can happily report that the only compilation error is due to the use of DateFormat. As I mentioned before, working around this is possibly using Calendar. As it turns out, bug 14982 discusses exactly this and Tom attached a patch he created to work around a similar problem:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=149892#c10
Thanks, and sorry for the fire drill.
The ee.minimum.jar I was using had been copied from the Equinox project org.eclipse.osgi straight out of CVS, so maybe that one needs to be updated. Maybe Tom knows.

Created an attachment (id=51448) Patch replacing DateFormat
Hi Simon,
I think you're proposing something like this patch. It seems fine and looks harmless as DateFormat is not central to the cm implemtation. Ruibin, does this patch work for you? (the patch sets the Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment, however I did not get a chance to try this in min 1.1 environment)
-- As an aside... One thing I'm less comfortable with is that this code will likely need to be repeated elsewhere. (see bug 142138) We can certainly commit a polished version of this patch, but I'd like to avoid creating future inconsistency if possible.

Created an attachment (id=51450) Patch replacing DateFormat
(missed the import in the last patch)

Yes, I tried the patch and it looks good. Sadly it is tricky to know where code such as this could reside such that others could use it. Maybe Tom can suggest somewhere.
The .classpath still needs to be updated since it refers to "CDC-1.0%Foundation-1.0".
Thanks
I also tried the patch, now it works fine on J9 with -JCL:RM.

(In reply to comment #3) > The ee.minimum.jar I was using had been copied from the Equinox project > org.eclipse.osgi straight out of CVS, so maybe that one needs to be updated. > Maybe Tom knows.
I have been reluctant to move the core Equinox framework off of ee min 1.0. This will temp us to start checking in code that will not run on older VMs. At some point this will become less important when the VMs that support ee min 1.1 have been released for a while.

(In reply to comment #6) > Yes, I tried the patch and it looks good. Sadly it is tricky to know where > code such as this could reside such that others could use it. Maybe Tom can > suggest somewhere.
It is difficult to pick such a place. I don't want to start adding more API to the Equinox framework for this.
[Patch submitted to HEAD] I've also updated and tested with an ee min 1.1 classpath as per Simon's suggestion. (I'll track the LogTracker differences in bug 142138)
Is this something that we could fix for R3.2.2?
No, org.eclipse.equinox.cm has not graduated from the incubator and does not exist in 3.2.2. We are looking to graduate it in 3.3.

bug.short_desc: Deleting a connection whose source/target is canonical automatically deletes the element

long_desc.thetext:
Let's say you had the following scenario... On a non-canonical diagram, you have a non-canonical shape that contains canonical border item. There is a non-canonical connection from the border item to another shape. If you delete the connection with the delete key, you would expect it to just be deleted from the diagram, but instead it deletes the relationship from the model.
The reason is that ConnectionEditPolicy.shouldDeleteSemantic() returns true if one of the ends is canonical. Actually, it should figure out if the connector itself is canonical.

Created an attachment (id=52551) suggested patch
Patch for DeleteFromDiagramAction and ConnectionEditPolicy.
Moving to 1.0.2 since this is deleting from a clients model rather than from the diagram.
Committed to R1_0_maintenance for Cherie

bug.short_desc: [Markers] Problems View filters using working sets include sub-packages

long_desc.thetext:
Assume the following package structure:
package/ sub1/ Sub1.java sub2/ Sub2.java Main.java
Assume Sub1 and Sub2 each have a problem, but Main does not have any problems.
1. In the Problems View menu, select "Configure Filters..." 2. Create a new working set (I'll call it "BugSet") 3. In the working set, include only the package 'package', but not package.sub1 or package.sub2 4. Create a new filter that uses BugSet as its Working Set, and enable only that filter.
I expect the problems list to show nothing, but it shows the problems in both Sub1 and Sub2.
I believe this is working as intended. All usages of working sets in the workbench behave this way.

Perhaps I did not see the means to obtain the behavior I'm looking for that someone could enlighten me in? Otherwise, it seems the UI has a lot of useless information. Selecting 'package' implicitly has the effect of selecting 'sub1' and 'sub2'. I can then subsequently select 'sub1' and 'sub2' themselves, but since I've already selected 'package', those UI actions are no-ops. That seems counter-intuitive to me, regardless if this is how all working sets work.

bug.short_desc: Porting org.eclipse.core.jobs to use declarative services

long_desc.thetext:
As a test of declarative services, I have changed the jobs plugin to use declarative services (not released to HEAD of course). I'm opening this bug as a place-holder to capture the work in progress, to make notes, and to allow others to try it out.
The goal was to make the org.eclipse.core.jobs plugin as OSGi-agnostic as possible. As much as possible, I want the standalone behaviour to be identical to the behaviour when running within OSGi.
The end result is that the plugin just requires org.eclipse.equinox.common, and three packages from org.eclipse.osgi for the two services that it uses (PackageAdmin and DebugOptions). The job plugin activator is removed, and the JobOSGiUtils class that registered the IJobManager service and created service trackers for the two services. The end result is marginally simpler than before.
The biggest problem was in activation lifecycle. Some plugins rely on IJobManager being available very early in the startup sequence. DS wants to instantiate the IJobManager service itself, and it wants to do it somewhat later in a background thread. This means there is a race to instantiate the JobManager, of which there must only ever be one. Usually DS loses the race, and there end up being two instances. The only way I could work around this is to create a proxy instance of IJobManager that just forwards all methods to the real singleton job manager. I register this proxy service implementation with DS, so I don't care if/when it gets activated. Perhaps there is a way to do this with a service factory, but I could not figure that out. The end result is somewhat less than optimal because it requires this proxy class, but it works and all the runtime test suites pass.
One other problem was in the shutdown sequence. Without a JobActivator, org.eclipse.core.jobs can't participate in the shutdown sequence. It previously used this opportunity to cancel all jobs and discard all worker threads. This has never worked properly in the standalone mode (bug 124968). The only solution I can find is to make all worker threads daemon threads. This means there is no error reporting if plugins fail to cancel all their jobs prior to shutdown. It would be nice if there was some way to allow a bundle to participate in the shutdown sequence while being OSGI-agnostic. I.e., have a stop() or shutdown() method on the component object with no parameters.
Another thought: when using a dependency injection system, a bundle needs to expose a semi-private API where the dependencies are injected, so that when running standalone there is a clear place for someone to inject dependencies manually without having unnecessary exposure to the rest of the implementation. It isn't clear how to treat this API wrt package naming, package exports, etc.
Created an attachment (id=51425) Patch to org.eclipse.core.jobs bundle
Created an attachment (id=51576) Latest patch
Just playing around...

Unfortunately the eclipse server definition is completely broken now. You have to delete it from the "Servers" view, otherwise it is not even possible to start it again.

Adding Rob to comment on the unpublish behavior.
Rob in this scenario step 3 actually removes the module from the server but then a second remove job comes on step 6 which is redundant. Is it really necessary to have this publish request?

OK, here is what I see occurring via some debugging (I was able to reproduce this with a generic WLS 9.2 adapter using 1.5.1), it is independent of project deletion and is related to either a error in the how the publish state for removed module is being updated; here is the test I performed:
-publish a dynamic web project to the server -remove the module from the server -execute a publish -the server adapters undeploy logic is correct executed and the module is correctly cleared from the .metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.wst.server.core/servers.xml file -execute a manual publish again on the server adapter; in ServerBehaviorDelegate.publish(), the call to addRemovedModules() is (incorrectly, I believe) adding a removed module for the already successfully removed project module (I believe this is because the publish state is not getting updated after the module is unpublished so the check against previously published modules to determine which module have been removed continues to return the same module)
A simple modification of GenericServerBehavior.removeFromServer() to set the publish state to PUBLISH_STATE_NONE if no errors occurred during the unpublish call (similar to the logic for the non-removal case in publishModule()) eliminates the problem.
Q: should publish state for removed modules be updated by server framework logic rather than server adapter logic in this case?

I vote for adapter logic since this is the best place to determine the success of publish/unpublish. Having said that I am also worried that these sorts of nifty details and lack of tests to confirm an adapter implementation is making it harder for others to create good quality implementations. Anyway I shall fix generic servers shortly.
Were you going to try to get this approved for 1.5.2?
It is a close call for 1.5.2, I will fix it for 2.0 for now
released to HEAD
Is it possible to get this into 1.5.3 ?
Gorkem, were you planning to target this for 1.5.3 or to set it for 2.0M3 and leave it there?
I will leave this as 2.0 since there is another bug 163715 for 1.5.3.
Verified against Eclipse 3.3M4 / WTP2.0M4, works fine now ! Closing.

bug.short_desc: [Preferences] PreferenceDialogUtil.createPropertyDialogOn should not restrict element to being an IAdaptable

long_desc.thetext:
3.2
We have an object that has an associated property page, but the object is not an IAdaptable. We currently have no proper API for opening the properties dialog on this object. The closest I could find is PreferenceDialogUtil.createPropertyDialogOn, but the element argument is typed as IAdaptable. I think this should be relaxed to allow an arbitrary Object.
We currently have a hack workaround whereby we have our own subclass of PropertyDialogAction (marked as not subclassable) with a custom selection provider that returns a selection with our object, and then run the action. It would be nice to clean this up.
There are currently no plans to work on this however I would be happy to look over a contribution

".classpath" looked this way: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <classpath> <classpathentry kind="src" path="src"/> <classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JRE_CONTAINER"/> <classpathentry kind="lib" path="C:/Temp/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.web_1.1.0.v200606152049.jar"/> <classpathentry kind="output" path="runtime"/> </classpath>

Or maybe the ".JETEmitters" project can be excluded from validation, as it is not reachable from inside eclipse. I remember cases where it contained compiler warnings which were quite annoying.

bug.short_desc: ICPPFunction allows mutable functions

long_desc.thetext:
According to section 7.1.1.8 of the April 2003 draft of the ISO C++ standard (14882:2003), functions aren't allowed to have the storage class "mutable".
Although the grammar allows it, the standard says it can only be applied to names of non-const/non-static/non-reference data members.
However, ICPPFunction declares the method isMutable().
Are there any variants of C++ that allow mutable functions? Or is it safe to take this out?

The grammar is allowed to be permissive with what it accepts. However, you are correct, the IASTNodes/IBindings/ITypes should not. I'm not sure if this an oversight. The Niefer had the spec open beside him for the two years he worked on this stuff so he would know best why it's there.

I confess that I didn't look particularily closely at the spec with regard to the mutable storage class specifier. We don't have any semantic code that cares about it.
Jason is correct, mutable does not apply to functions. And in fact, neither do register or auto which appear on IFunction. (I double checked the C spec as well for those two).
The only variant that we made an effort to support is GCC, so I would expect these are safe to remove.
For reference sake, we used 14882:1998 for C++ and 9899:1999 for C.

bug.short_desc: Swing memory leak

long_desc.thetext: Please don't remove a single line. Make a stand alone snippet that shows the problem and we can look into it.
Reopen this bug report when you have the code.

I have the same problem. I wrote a snippet in order to isolate possible dependencies from my code trying to simulate the same situation: embedding AWT controls in a SWT Composite by means of the SWT_AWT.new_Frame method, which returns an AWT Frame object (sun.awt.windows.WEmbeddedFrame in fact) where you can add AWT components. By monitoring the performance by means of a tool called JProfiler, I can see that the reference count of both the Frame class and an AWT Label added to it increments every time I repeat the operation of disposing the Composite object, creating a new one and executing again the SWT_AWT.new_Frame method. It is supposed that disposing the Composite object should release the memory it and all its dependent components are taking up, but it seems this is not happening
Ok, better look at this.
SSQ, I am brutally sick right now. Can you follow up with this guy? He is trying to ship.

Please could you provide the snippet you wrote?
This could be the same bug as https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=127374.

We opened the Task Manager and watched the memory. We were able to create and dispose more than 500 SWT_AWT frames and memory stayed around 18Mb. What VM are you using? Ours is:
java version "1.5.0_02" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_02-b09) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_02-b09, mixed mode)

I repeated again the test and I could see that despite the profiler I'm using shows that the reference count increases (which in this case represents a very small amount of memory, even repeating 500 times the operation), if I wait enough time, the garbage colector finally clears them up. In fact, I was working these days in improving our code in order to eliminate the problem as much as possible, and although I still have some reference counts that never decrease, after modifying several things, the application is not expected to hang with the current situation. I apologize for the time you have spent with my problem. Thanks a lot anyway
